column1: Low-Fat Dietary Pattern Intervention and Health-Related Quality of Life: The Women's Health Initiative Randomized Controlled Dietary Modification Trial.
column2: A. Assaf, S. Beresford, P. Risica, A. Aragaki, R. Brunner, D. Bowen, M. Naughton, M. Rosal, L. Snetselaar, N. Wenger
column5: Journal of the Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics
column9:
- Total sample size: 48,835
- Gender breakdown: All female
- Mean age: Not reported (range: 50 to 79 years, most represented group: 60 to 69 years)
- Inclusion/exclusion criteria: Inclusion: fat intake ≥32% of total calories; Exclusion: prior colorectal or breast cancer, recent other cancers, type 1 diabetes, medical conditions with predicted survival <3 years
- Baseline health or dietary status: 38% obese, 36% overweight; alcohol consumption: <10% more than one drink/day; smoking: approximately 7%; multivitamin use: 36%; physical activity: averaged 10 METs/week
column10:
- Type of dietary change: Low-fat dietary pattern
- Duration of dietary intervention: Ongoing with 18 group sessions in the first year and quarterly sessions thereafter
- Specific dietary recommendations or guidelines: Reduce total dietary fat intake to 20%, increase vegetables and fruit to at least 5 servings a day, increase grain servings to at least 6 servings a day
- Method of dietary assessment: WHI food frequency questionnaire (FFQ)
column11:

- Specific well-being domains measured: General health, physical functioning, vitality, role physical, bodily pain, social functioning, role emotional, mental health, sleep quality
- Numerical results for well-being outcomes: Differential changes at Year 1 - General health: 1.7 units (95% CI 1.5, 2.0), Physical functioning: 2.0 units (95% CI 1.7, 2.3), Vitality: 1.9 units (95% CI 1.6, 2.2), Global quality of life: 0.09 units (95% CI 0.07, 0.12). At close-out: Physical functioning: 0.8 units, Vitality: 1.0 units, General health perceptions: 0.6 units
column12: No additional outcomes reported. The paper focuses on dietary intake changes and HRQoL measures, with no mention of physiological markers or physical activity levels as additional outcomes.

column14:
- "This randomized controlled trial was analyzed as intent to treat."

  - "The DM trial in the WHI was a randomized controlled trial designed to test the hypothesis that a reduction of fat intake to 20 percent of the total daily calories and an increase in the intake of fruit, vegetables, and whole grains would reduce the risk of breast cancer and of colorectal cancer and, as a secondary outcome, the risk of heart disease in postmenopausal women."
  - "All analyses were based on the intention-to-treat principle using SAS (version 9.1, 2002, SAS Institute Inc)."
  - "The primary nutrition goal of the WHI DM intervention was to reduce total dietary fat intake to 20% of energy."
column16:

- The study design is consistently described as a randomized controlled trial throughout the paper, with no mention of other study designs such as cohort or before-and-after studies.
